The function \\( x(t) \\) evolves according to the differential equation \\( x'(t) = Kx(t) \\) with initial condition \\( x(0) = x_0 \\), and the Laplace transform \\( X(s) \\) is defined as \\( X(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{x(t)\\}(s) = \\int_0^{\\infty} e^{-st}x(t)dt \\).

If the function \\( x(t) \\) is transformed by \\( \\mathcal{L} \\) into \\( X(s) \\) and then allowed to return to the time domain via the inverse Laplace transform without any intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) at any time \\( t \\) be the same as if it had been evolved directly from \\( x_0 \\) under \\( x'(t) = Kx(t) \\)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform and its inverse form a bijective transformation pair, meaning that transforming \\( x(t) \\) into the frequency domain and back again, with no other alteration, will faithfully reconstruct the original function \\( x(t) \\) as evolved from \\( x_0 \\) under \\( x'(t) = Kx(t) \\). Thus, the effect is same as the original evolution.
